needing to manage multiple versions and multiple stages of their apis the main

don't consider API Keys themselves to be a security mechanism we also support the
um use of different security mechanisms on top of API keys so that you can actually not only monitor using API key
usage but you can also control who's accessing your
API because of the nature of API Gateway where we can enable throttling caching
and so forth and we have the uh scaling capability to handle whatever the

and you can apply different caches to different versions so for instance let's say you had a stage that was for beta

and so your apis hosted with us benefit from and inherit that dos protection

of presence we look to see whether the results from the API call have already

Now API Keys you can create them you can deploy them you can hand them out to

if you give out your key that gives them access to that stage for instance if you give it out to customers who you want to

there's a certain select me uh set of customers who do have access and so you can create those as you'd as you'd
expect we also tie into Amazon cloudwatch logs so you can at any point
go and query your logs to see who's been accessing it how often and so
on but as I said already we do not consider API Keys themselves to be a form of security they're a form of
metering uh anybody who relies purely on API Keys as a form of security is liable
not to end up with uh control over their API where they can specifically track
the calls to the client um it's if anybody has actually tried to pull an ex
existing mobile application uh onto their uh development environment and then crack it open you'll probably see
the textual key there and you can pull it out you can drop into your app and then as far as that person's as far as
that back end providers concerned it's still the original app that's calling not your app that is not a secure
mechanism so while we support this and we think it's a great feature for you to use for your metering and monitoring we
do not recommend this as a security mechanism for security we suggest you use something
like aws's signature version 4 or sigv4 which is a mechanism we use for
authentication and authorization between different AWS services some of you may already know this um or honestly you
could use any other mechanism such as oor the thing is in those instances
you'll pass the token through a custom header API Gateway will do a direct pass through to your back end of that custom
header and your own back end will in those cases do the uh implementation of handling that oor or whatever ronm
you're using so it's extensible in that sense but the inherent support is with
sigv4 and if you're used to using Cognito uh which is another uh service

Gateway Login where the parameters would be let's say username and password the
Lambda function we'll take that username and password we'll check against the U
user database account database they have if it comes back it can then go and
request against Cognito to get a temporary um authorization token from

from then on that client would then use that token that had been vended to it with all of your API calls and we'll

okay I'm going to go into throttling and caching now throttling shouldn't be a big
surprise enables you to use API um API Gateway as a means of uh protecting your
back end so that uh it doesn't get flooded with uh calls if your application suddenly takes
off you you the developer Define what the uh limits are for throttling and
that can be a rate limit in terms of the standard throughput as well as a peak limit uh if they start backing up and
what's particularly good here is that we uh if you do hit that throttling point where you've said I don't want my back
end have to handle more than x um calls uh transactions per second we will
return a 429 HTP error and your client can handle that and retry and with the
with the generated sdks we actually have that code already built in and we do an exponential backoff for retries
so again if you are building your application and you take the uh you benefit from the use of the SDK that's

authentication uh tying in with Cognito for um sigv4 and we also handle the
retries in these instances for caching I mentioned this a
little earlier you can choose to provision a cache for your API if you choose to you can do this on a per API
or a per stage basis caches come in varying different sizes from half a gig to 237 gigs and the way they work is
based upon the keys certain keys of data that come in you can specify for this
key value please cache the results uh that I'm about to return and that that
way any call that comes in API Gateway will do a comparison of is this key in
the cache if it is then it already knows the response that you would your back end would normally send and it will send it straight out now that is an API call
so it does count as an API call to API Gateway but it therefore doesn't hit your back end so it's a way to actually
help uh reduce uh back um load on your back end as well as actually speeding up
uh calls to your back end and this is just a diagram that
helps illustrate that process a call comes in from any of the clients we check to see whether the value is there
if it is we'll return it straight away if not we continue through the system we look to see whether API Gateway is
taking in more calls than you provisioned it to do so if it is return a 429 otherwise send it through to the
back end that you've set up now with data
Transformations this is kind of an interesting story where we've added additional um execution knowledge into
the API Gateway layer what it does is it means that your
back end can actually be used for multiple reasons and multiple ways even if it wasn't how it was originally um
